items.title: Audio long read: Faulty mitochondria cause deadly diseases — fixing them is about to get a lot easier
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03797-9 Researchers have struggled to precisely edit mitochondrial DNA, but new techniques are bringing this ability within reach.

items.title: Laser cooling traps more antimatter atoms than ever before
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03877-w Studying trapped antimatter could help to explain why our world is so full of matter.

items.title: Momentum mixing solves the Mott problem
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03104-3 Adding momentum mixing in a controllable way to the exactly solvable Hatsugai–Kohmoto model is shown to recover the physics of the Hubbard model, the starting point for understanding Mott physics. The scheme converges as the inverse square of the number of steps, and, as each step is tractable, minimal computational resources are required.

items.title: Quantum superconducting diode effect with perfect efficiency above liquid-nitrogen temperature
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03098-y A device for rectifying supercurrents at liquid-nitrogen temperature with high efficiency is demonstrated. This is a practical step towards implementing dissipationless electronics.

items.title: Maternal histone methyltransferases antagonistically regulate autosomal random monoallelic expression (aRMAE) in C. elegans
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66501-5 Random monoallelic expression affects everything from the penetrance of genetic disease to immune cell function. Here, the authors found that epigenetic monoallelic expression is regulated in early embryos by two conserved maternal histone methyltransferases.

items.title: Elimination of a neutrophil Pad4 byproduct restores stem cell–mediated bone regeneration in hyperglycemia
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66935-x Here they show that high blood sugar drives neutrophils to release 4-GBA, a Pad4 byproduct that blocks bone-forming stem cells. A peptide gel that traps 4-GBA restores jawbone healing in rats, rabbits and dogs, suggesting a local, immune-sparing therapy.

items.title: Kinetically controlled hetero-fusion is a systems-level behaviour of polymer nanoparticle populations
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66827-0 Particle fusion is a promising process for constructing nanomaterials, but challenging to control in synthetic systems. Here, the authors report a method for kinetically regulated particle fusion controlled by variation in polymer chain length.

items.title: Structure of an LGR dimer, an evolutionary predecessor of glycoprotein hormone receptors
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66676-x Metazoans have evolved endocrine systems that signal through dimerized receptors in response to cognate hormones. These authors characterize a nematode homolog of such human receptors, presenting the cryo-EM structure of an asymmetric dimer that embodies properties of the human receptors.

items.title: Piezo1-mediated mechanotransduction controls osteocyte maturation and dendrite development via a YAP-CCN-Src signaling axis
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65636-9 Mechanical force controls bone development and homeostasis. Here, the authors show that Piezo1-driven YAP–CCN1/2 signalling is essential for osteocyte maturation and dendrite formation.

items.title: Synthesis of bimetallic MOFs via interface control using gallium-based liquid metal
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66942-y This study reports a liquid metal interface-controlled electrochemical approach that enables anodic growth of bimetallic ZnMg-MOF-74, previously limited to single-metal systems. The derived ZnMgO shows ultraviolet photoresponse for photodetection.

items.title: Translocation mechanism of xeroderma pigmentosum group D protein on single-stranded DNA and genetic disease etiology
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66834-1 This computational modelling study unveils the detailed DNA translocation mechanisms of two archetypal SF2 family helicases, XPD and DinG, and sheds light on the functional impact of XPD-associated mutations on genetic disease etiology.

items.title: Mechanical confinement induces ferroptosis through mitochondrial dysfunction
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66353-z A groundbreaking study reveals how physical confinement triggers ferroptosis. It finds the nucleus acts as a mechanosensor, orchestrating Drp1 and cPLA2 that leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and ultimately, cell death.

items.title: Super-expansive thermo-reversible interstitial solid solution of nanocrystal superlattices with mesogens
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02388-3 Combining liquid crystals and nanocrystals functionalized with promesogenic ligands yields an interstitial colloidal solid solution exhibiting high thermal expansivity and reversible superlattice phase transitions driven by mesogen diffusion.

items.title: Self-assembled cell-scale containers made from DNA origami membranes
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02418-0 Through the programmable self-assembly of lipid-inspired radially symmetric DNA, porous molecular membranes and cell-sized compartments are formed with applications in bottom-up biology and soft robotics.

items.title: Twisting the Hubbard model into the momentum-mixing Hatsugai–Kohmoto model
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 27 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03095-1 The Hubbard model describes the physics of strongly correlated electron systems, but is difficult to solve.
